I assume you are talking about dopamine when you say "it feels good", actually this is a misunderstanding, dopamine is not the "feel good" chemical, opioids do that

Dopamine is what your brain uses to focus on things, if you could press a button that releases dopamine immediately in your brain, you would pay way more attention to whatever you are doing . Dopamine is also released after you finish the task you are working on . This also applies with thoughts and sensations, so when you are feeling something and doing something, the more dopamine (aka the more focused you are), the more associations between stuff is made in your brain .
That's why dopamine is associated with addiction because it is what makes your body expect things like alcohol and opioids. In alcohol, both dopamine and endogenous opioids are involved, the opioids cause the feelings addicted people want to replicate, but dopamine really is what makes it hard to forget the feeling. It's what makes the Pavlov dogs salivate

Hmmm. Well, I certainly can notice the positive/negative response to image contrast and low audio, but I'm really not sure about the repetition of names and phrases. I think the the nature of repetition with regards to cognitive ease is more complicated than just a straight proportional relationship.

If I consider my own reactions to repetition, when a name/phrase is repeated and it doesn't relate to anything significant within my mind, it's confusing/irritating as I try to figure out why I should find it familiar. If a name/phrase is identified with negative content (or negative actions) inside my mind, then the more I hear it, the more irritation and dislike I feel towards the subject (e.g. Donald Trump, the Cardashians, Megan Markle), while if a name/phrase is identified with positive content, I feel positive towards it (and hence feel cognitive ease). A combination of negative and positive information associated with the one subject creates caution and skepticism as I try to more critically figure out what the situation is.

In other words: What the subject of repetition is actually related to creates a positive or negative association (and thus cognitive ease or not). This creates a bias, but I am also cognisant that the less reliable information I have about the subject ,the less reliable my opinion is. 

Scientific skepticism and analytical thinking is certainly necessary (especially on the internet), even though it can take effort to question the more instinctive type of confirmation bias. But then again, today's version of skepticism can be a way for people to dismiss what seems unfamiliar or foreign to their everyday lives. E.g. there is no scientific reason that ancient people didn't develop more advanced technology than we actually think they did, but it sounds ridiculous to most people, no matter how limited their knowledge of archeology.

....Although, I'm "intuitively" pretty skeptical that unhappiness helps great thought. You'd think that the more unhappy you were, the more depressed and preoccupied your mind would be with your own suffering, making it more difficult to concentrate on analytical thinking.

Great video.  It misses an important side issue though: People are more likely to suffer from cognitive ease if their life is more stressful.  Peoples lives are more stressful because they suffer from decision fatigue.  One significant reason people suffer from decision fatigue is a lack of discipline/temperance to form/implement habits/routines/rituals in their lives.  Habits/routines/rituals are repetitive tasks that, once they are well learnt, no longer require decision making.  The more of one's basic aspects of life (or even more complicated stuff) that are converted habits the more cognitive energy is freed up to enable you to be less stressed and more happily engage the conscious mind on what is in front of you.

It's amazing how this 5-year-old post is still getting thoughtful comments, along with many that reflect the deep divisions with the United States. A common theme is that only some media can be trusted, or that no mainstream media can ever be trusted. Others ask, “Who can I trust, or do I have to develop skills so I can know who is telling the truth?” Well, here's my take on it...

With complex topics, I don't have the time or the skill to become to a subject-matter expert. There are others who have studied for a decade or more to become experts, such as epidemiologists and climatologists. They never stop learning and teaching. They publish scholarly papers that are peer-reviewed, and in turn they review the papers of their peers. In this way the body of knowledge grows and is shared, and theories that fail this process fall by the wayside. It’s not failsafe, but history supports the view that it is self-correcting. So, for fields such as pandemics and global warming, I turn to these subject matter experts and the media that gives them air-time. I particularly look to media that publishes long-form articles that allow me to understand these complex topics.

In Australia we’re fortunate that the state and federal governments’ pandemic responses are shaped by their subject-matter experts. I wish I could say the same for global warming.

The problem with this is that repetition isn't universally processed with cognitive ease. /Very/ often, repetition leads to something being considered significantly less favourably. For example, with the K*rdashi*ns, their ubiquity commonly leads to disgust and ire. Or songs on the radio that might've been nice at first, but then you get absolutely SICK of it being everywhere. Repetition can make things seem more obnoxious, rather than innocuous. Much like when you eat a food too much and then get sick of it. And this also extends to factoids. There is an "oh not that again" effect. Like that "glass is a liquid" thing, or the tongue-map theory. Increased exposure to something can easily instead lead to disdain. I call it the Funko Pop Effect, personally, given how many people hate them and call them ugly. They're ubiquitous, but if they weren't, and if people only saw them extremely rarely, they'd likely think they were simple and cute.

The other thing is that repeated exposure is what /allows/ people to notice its flaws. More time seeing something means more noticing. Now, obviously, sometimes, there aren't flaws, because sometimes something /is/ simply true, or the flaws are minor edge-cases that don't affect the core essence of the thing or statement. It depends. It varies. But, often, increased exposure means /thinking/ about it more, and therefore questioning it, and finding flaws and exceptions.

And the irony is that I've so often heard "the more something is repeated, the more it starts to feel true", but then, even this video trying to argue that doesn't make that feel more true. It makes it feel /less/ true, because having this increased familiarity with the concept led to thinking about it more, and noticing the flaws and counterexamples.

The other thing is that this probably has some relation to the Semmelweis reflex as well, which is something that we need to be more aware of, and be willing and able to overcome.

But also, there is a difference between cognitive ease and thin-slicing. Cognitive ease isn't more likely to lead to a correct gut-intuition. It only indicates a general amount of exposure, and one that leads to a bias, rather than indicating /extraction of information/, which is what thin-slicing is. And this video seemed to conflate the two.

We really do all need to think critically more often. That /doesn't/ equate to or necessitate analysis-paralysis. Thin-slicing is helpful. Cognitive-ease, not really so much.

Yep, this tactic is used a lot by companies and marketing firms. We tend to dislike new sounding songs so what do they do? Make most songs sound the same sense you're already familiar with that sound. Combined with the familiar face of an artist who's plastered everywhere records sell a lot faster and become popular really quickly. And if you didn't like a new song at first just wait until the song is played on the radio over and over, in Walmart and at clubs. Next thing you know you've grown accustomed to it.

From my understanding the general theory is that thousands of years ago hearing a new sound in the jungle was the potential for a new threat. We're way more likely to assume it's a threat than not because back in the day it was a matter of life and death. We're very loss averse. You're more likely to miss out on an opportunity to gain more money than lose what you already have.

If a caveman back in the day saw a bunch of fruit that happened to be in the same area they saw a sabertooth once, the situation might play out like this: The caveman decides to stay away from that area and find food elsewhere and thus lives on for many years afterwards. Or he might take a chance and grab the fruit multiple times over a month but one day is unlucky and crosses paths with the sabertooth he saw and dies. Now that month of gathering fruit to eat was essentially useless compared to if he had avoided it and lived with less food but wasn't eaten.

The problem these days though with that loss aversion is we have it in most every aspect of our decision making. But in modern times the majority of our decisions aren't a matter of life and death and sometimes a little risk taking could even be advantageous.

I feel like there is a motif (Easter egg? Nagging concern of the content creator?) that the people who watch Veritasium may not be learning in the true sense of the word, but rather experiencing some sensation that is similar to learning but which does not actually impart lasting knowledge in the viewer.

If this is true (that it is an oft-inserted question/concern of the content creator about the instrinsic value of his videos to his viewers), then I’d like to weigh in on the question.

I have spent time debating this question myself, not just about the time I spend on this creator’s videos but all such channels that I spend time watching. From that self-reflection and assessment I can say with a high degree of certainty that, at least in the singular case of me, I retain and “learn” quite a bit more from Veritasium videos than pretty much any other media source. The topics covered are so frequently novel, unique, and applicable for purposes down the road. The only other media source that even comes close I would say is Last Week Tonight with John Oliver, although the topics he covers are more so obscure-but-important societal issues that makes for a apples-to-oranges comparison to the topics covered here.

That’s not to say there are no Veritasium videos that I experience the sensation of learning without actually learning from. The math incompleteness theory video made me feel like mind=blown while watching but now looking back I can’t say I recall enough even to do a Tim Allen level recitation of what I learned from watching it. That one might take two or three more watches to make any headway in terms of real learning.

That said, even if a video is merely entertaining, my judgement is that ought be enough at least to justify the effort, for most people, in most situations. Then again though, I tend to be one of those oddly-comfortable-with-cognitive-unease types of people.

All that is to say, thanks Veritasium for making such incredible content. Yours is truly one of a kind on this modern invention called YouTube.

@Veritasium, the multiple choice text with 2 different fonts was unscientific. I'll explain why.
The assumption if that the only difference between the two was that the one in the 'fancy' font was harder to read. But in reality, what were the differences?
a) The 'fancy' font was more visually appealing. Hence for many this will mean more pleasant to read.
b) The fancy font was justified - i.e. was made visually symmetrical by arranging the lines in this visually appealing way.
c) The fancy text used capital letters to start each line.

Factors b) and c) both have an effect in changing the perception of the material. Specifically, the 'plain' font will I believe on average tend the reader to a more linear reading of the text. It's a single block and you read through it sequentially. Whereas the fancy one presents the information in a more explicitly divided set of 3 parts, 3 separate statements all justified centre and all starting with capital letters. This I suggest will on average encourage the reader, more than the 'plain' text, to set these 3 statements in their mind and thus be better able to test the relationships between them in their mind.

I am not negating the possibility that some modern readers might find it somewhat harder to read a font closer to human handwriting. But it's these other variables that have, in my opinion, invalidated this experiment. And I would propose a re-test but if possible not even changing the letter size or spacing, only the shape of the individual letters of the font, trying to minimise variables. You might even try it with various different fonts if you have enough participants to test. A font that is harder to read but 'ugly'; one that is harder but 'beautiful', and also for the easy to read ones, an 'ugly' one and a beautiful one. And perhaps a 'neutral' one of each also.

Such a test, under the additional requirements I mentioned above, should be able to not only tell the effect of the difficulty in reading, but also measure to some degree the emotional effect on the result. We are after all emotional beings, so our reading is not only about ease or difficulty of comprehension.

The title of this video is misleading. First, it has nothing to do with truth itself, the “illusory” part addressing epistemology and not ontology. Second, judging things as good or bad are value judgements, not truth-value judgements. More "cognitive ease" = Less "cognitive effort".
That's how I've always seen these things.

Energy is a precious thing to creatures because it's the difference between life and death, so humans instinctively seek to minimize effort expended.
This is why when to see people trying to get into a building they will wait in a line to go through a door that's already open rather than just opening another one and going in right away.
Someone has already expended the effort so I can save my own.

Clear high contrast images and audio require less processing in the brain which saves energy which means you'll live longer without adding additional energy.
That feels good.

By contrast, if you're sitting in your cage in the winter watching your food run out, it makes you feel anxious because the odds that you and your family will die increase.
This is why people eat more than they need to, it feels good to have an oversupply.

When you first see a Kardashian you have to think, "what the hell is that, and why is it there?"
Next time you see one, you have fewer questions, which requires less cognitive effort and this energy to solve, which means you are further from running out and dying.
The hundredth time you see a Kardashian it is so common you don't have to expand any cognitive effort at all, which feels good partly because you don't have to worry about making the effort to find more energy to replace the energy you used too spend figuring things out.

But familiarity can create false expectations, like when you see a word many times so you start to think you know what it means when you don't, or when you see a person so often you feel at ease around them when they might actually be a threat, you've just guessed that if they haven't hurt you before, odds are they won't change now, even though they might.

So in a sense what you are talking about is the instinctive urge to conserve energy to survive longer on the energy you have, because you know that acquiring energy requires energy, and you can never be sure that the energy your expend will be worth it in terms of how much you acquire; just because you look for food doesn't mean you'll find any.

I doubt if this documentary is true. It seems applicable to those who spend an enormous amount of time being mesmerized by the thousands of flashing lights that create a computer screen,  which is almost everyone born in the last thirty years.  My generation, on the other hand, can easily put down a book and change tasks.  Also, most importantly, our schooling involved word and sentence structure, probability, analytical thinking and history.  Fact checking was done in the Library, which contained three types of books;  Fiction, Non-Fiction and Reference.  The computer only offers one kind of information ---Opinion. The fake words would never have fooled me because I learned to discover the meaning of a new word in a dictionary before I continued reading.  Analytical thinking is merely applying the question "Why?"  to every idea presented to me.   I notice when something is repeated, such as the term "gaslighting", and wonder why.  I heard the name Einstein many times before I was old enough and smart enough to understand his genius.  Everyone knows why Abraham Lincoln and Marlon Brando are famous.  Eventually I had to find out why the Kardashians were famous.  The appalling answer to that question may have been what initially started me wondering what was happening as people replaced books with tweets.  We are entering a frightening Orwellian Tower of Babel world where an increasingly large slice of society is finding its only alternative is to arm itself against the inevitable day of defending their food supply.  My advice is to doubt everything until you satisfy yourself as to why someone said or did or believed a particular thing.  Was it to teach, share or fool you?   Are they selling something or giving something away?  Advertisers control the flow of money on the internet and no one influences the accuracy of the information.  Therefore, everything on the internet is for sale and there is no way to easily determine whether something is fiction or non-fiction.  Good luck with your future.

4. Complex Perceptual Truth
In the article, before you, each field is explained in detail and shows that absolute truth is attainable and in fact, we live it every day, absolutely.


1. Simple Natural Truth
This is the science of facts. Simple natural truths are the facts of materialistic life — the sciences: physics, biology, chemistry, etc. A simple natural truth will come in the form of a statement of fact. For example, the Sun is a star in the universe. This is a proven scientific fact. Certain Flora utilizes chlorophyll to convert sunlight into energy; this is a proven biological fact. The molecular structure of a Hydrogen atom has a one-electron shell; this is a fact of molecular physics. Salt is made up of Sodium Nitrate; this is a chemical fact.
Another context of this kind of truth is the science or philosophy of facts. The known natural world is abundant with facts. These basic facts are global if not cosmic in their scope. Such facts as mentioned above and many others of a similar nature are the basis of a unified language. The physical universe is abundant with natural facts, truths, all making up the functions of physical existence. Natural facts, indisputable facts are simple natural truths.
Summary: Simple Natural Truths are indisputable facts no matter which forms of intelligence were to perceive them.

2. Complex Natural Truth
These are the partially proven theories and facts of discovery. Einstein's Unified field theory is an unproven theory based on scientific facts. It is a complex truth, however, to fully appreciate a complex natural truth, let us review the problem of a fusion energy unit. Cold Fusion energy is a theoretical fact; a truth that states that by forcing molecule and atoms to compress into themselves, the energies released will be extreme in comparison to the energy expended in the compression process. This theory in a more scientific gender is an unproven theory of physics but is a mixture of simple natural truths and human theoretic. The general consensus of scientists has proven theoretically beyond any doubt, that such a process is possible, as it is already being done in the Sun and other stars, in the explosions of nuclear weapons and other such large energy sources. Therefore, the complex natural truth is that an artificially stable and controllable fusion energy unit can be realized.
Complex facts, facts based upon theories partially proven, some non-provable but theoretically sound such as the theories of the reasons for existence, facts that are negative rather than positive are all a form of complex natural truths. Medicine is abundant with complex natural facts, all dealing with diagnoses, treatments, and results.
Summary: Complex Natural Truths are truths of unsubstantiated facts that are reached by any intelligence no matter how they perceive them.

3. Simple Perceptual Truth
A simple perceptual truth is the personal truth of every self-aware living organism — for example, two people sitting on a park bench both experiences similar but different facts. Let us expand this a stage, the sun is shining, the sky is clear, the mean temperature is 28 degrees Celsius, the park bench was painted dark green, and the sky is an azure blue.
One person feels the temperature and translates it as being warm, this is the perception of heat by the body and is a biological fact. It is the person's perceptual truth. The other person feels cold; the second person feels it is also a perceptual truth. If they were to discuss the weather, one would say to the other "It is warm today," the others reply might be "The sun is shining, but I feel Cold." Here we receive a contradiction of perceptual truths based on natural facts. The temperature is a natural fact, a truth of nature. The human's body to discern temperature and translate equally along a human race mean is a medical fact. However, each human organism feels heat differently for biological and mental reasons. Both people feel the temperature. Differently, both experience a perception of a natural fact and thus reach a perceptual truth based on their own realities.
One person might say the sky is azure; the other might say it is cyan. The human visual senses differ for each person. The extremes are color blindness. However, there are other organisms that see at different wavelengths and colors. Thus, color is a personal perception of a natural fact, a perceptual truth.
No matter how we analyze our surroundings, each person's perception is different, and each person concludes differently based on the information perceived.
Summary: Simple Perceptual Truths are the facts as perceived by any single intelligent entity.

4. Complex Perceptual Truth
The final limb of truth is the complex perception of an idea. This truth is based on the views of a human mind. One mind might perceive that a totalitarian society utilizing the truths developed by the suggesting mind is the only way society might reach utopia. This is a perception of a system for many, rather than a personal perception of a natural fact.
The way in which complex perceptual truths are utilized differs per person. Some try to explain, others use force and yet a third group might keep the idea a secret.
Complex perceptual truths require the acceptance of a number of individuals believing in the same set of mental ideas rather than a set of physiological feelings. Religion is a classic example of complex perceptual truth, whereby the belief in a deity and the ritual to appease such deity as agreed to and performed by a number of individuals in the presence of a complex perceptual truth. Theology is an example in applying the scientific method to belief and the Thomas Aquinas’ “leap of faith” is an example of non-rational behavior in order to prove a complex perceptual truth.
Summary: Complex Perceptual Truths are the facts as perceived equally by a group of intelligent entities or as perceived by a single intelligent entity and enforced or persuaded upon a group of other single entities who perceive it equally or indifferently, however, the case may be.

Conclusions
We live in a world of contradictions where belief and scientific method meet head-on in the daily argument. Truth is about reality and fiction since truth is a concept coined by the human animal. Truth has been shown to be about facts, scientific facts proven via the scientific method. However, the truth is also about perception and understanding of our environment and our interaction with other humans. This interaction and perception on an individual level as well as on a plural level lead to truths both individual and plural. They are true for they are perceptions of ideas and beliefs that cannot be disproved or proven by scientific method since their complexity is infinite, taking into account individual interactivity within its own mind or within a group and part of a groups mindset and as such go beyond any scientific methodology to prove a naturally proven fact or truth.

5:14
Yeah that's the thing I don't have. That synesthetic magic that neurotypical people have. x_x So that's what it's called (5:21) huh? I just referred to it as abstract association, although that's a bit vague. I never really thought about some of these things being related so I just thought they were separate issues, but thinking back on it and connecting the dots that makes a ton of sense.

Language is one of those inherent synesthetic abilities I lack, so communication is always a conscious effort for me. When I come up with what to say it's the same process as when I'm doing math, and I think everyone goes through the same mental process when doing math homework so you can get the idea from that. Basically I have to actually go back through all my memories to find associations in order to translate my thoughts into something people can perceive, so that creates significant limits. Not so much because of the time like you're probably thinking, but because there're so many possibilities it's hard to guess which one is correct in the moment.

I mean time is a problem too, but since the world is basically in slow motion for me I can track through quite a lot of memories in a short time. Understanding information is a lot faster than translating my thoughts correctly though. Most words don't have a ton of different meanings, so it's not often that hard to quickly find the associations in my memories.

The problem is that everyone else makes tons of illogical inferences and assumptions, getting all kinds of unrelated interpretations to different words and word orders that change at different times with no distinctive pattern. It can take hours to write a long message (like this one) because I have to check all my memories and run scenarios in my head in an effort to predict how the person will take it. Otherwise I might end up in a situation where I was just be asking if someone enjoyed their visit and they leave thinking I believe their grandmother is goat or whatever random nonsense people come up with.

So that's one thing, but then like with the gullible thing you mentioned I didn't even realize that was related. I just never understood why people were so easily manipulated by such mundane things, it never made sense to me. I understood subliminal messaging as a manipulation of our dumb subconscious which can't distinguish the difference between the thing we like being shown (happy family, cute dog, whatever) and the product, and then giving us that positive emotion when we later go looking to purchase that new whatever we need. However I didn't realize that was the same thing as why people like someone for no good reason, or judge nonsense words positively because they saw them more. I mean my brain just doesn't work like that, so I can't know exactly what it's all like for people who do experience that unless it's explained.

Plus when I was a kid I was widely considered extremely gullible, so that was a significant setback towards my grasping that association. It doesn't make sense that gullibility is an aspect of a cognitive function that I don't have, until one realizes that "gullible" isn't a trait (like how people use the word) but rather refers to an effect. In this case both the trait "cognitive ease" and the lack of the trait can cause someone to be fooled.

My lack of cognitive ease causes gullibility by the fact that I don't subconsciously perceive any difference between lying and telling the truth, I don't have a "gut feeling" so my only option is conscious analysis. A skill which I wasn't very good at as a child while I was still developing it. So that lack of intuition was what I always thought people were referring to by the word "gullible."

I can see there's a lot of benefits to the trait, but overall I'd say lacking it is more beneficial in modern society. At least for someone with decent intelligence, the downsides well exampled by the stereotype for nonverbal type autistics like myself. However that stereotype isn't even about people with autism, it's about people with mental retardation (a technical definition for someone of an IQ below 70; the antonym of genius) who also has autism.

Since both are quite rare it's extremely rare for someone to have both issue, but when they do it does make it impossible to communicate. Thanks to that stereotype though when most people with autism come out they're met with "Omg, you're autistic?! You don't look autistic."

IQ is unrelated to autism or any of the other cognitive conditions, being a specific thing in and of itself having to do with separate genetic factors related more to physical development than the mind. Like everyone else, the majority of autistics are of average intelligence and don't have significant trouble functioning in society. Maybe labelled as mean or cold due to lacking an understanding of cognitive ease, but do just as well in school and other tasks. There's a reason why data indicates that it's the most often mental condition for doctors to fail to diagnose.

Similarly a person who is retarded does poorly in school, but otherwise fits in fine in society. Given average social aptitude and the ability to excel in nontechnical fields, like sanitation, sports, acting, et cetera. Actually nowadays there are special education program designed to teach to their strengths so that they can graduate high school, and even go on to a technical school or something if they want.

Because they can have decent to good social skills, they're ironically less likely to be taken for someone with mental retardation than someone who is just socially awkward. I'm not sure how the general public constantly mixes up social intelligence (EQ) with academic intelligence (IQ). But I've digressed from the point, so I'll get back to that.

Sure I can't inherently know if someone is being sarcastic, asking a rhetorical question, nor infer usually inaccurate nonsense from meaningless things like tone which can be altered by something as simple as room temperature. But do those things really benefit society? I also can't intentionally lie because I don't understand how cognitive ease works, I can't be fooled by lies anymore because knowing it's a possibility I always use conscious analysis, I'm immune to manipulation that relies on cognitive ease, even that issue he mentioned about taking 30 minutes to pick a toothbrush hasn't been one since I was a kid because I've developed mental systems of quantifying value so I can make decisions quickly like simple math, and if everyone lacked cognitive ease I wouldn't have to spend any more time than anyone else on messages because I wouldn't have to worry that people were going to have some insane interpretation of the words I'm using to express the concepts I'm trying to share.

The title is essentially nihilistic, and the majority of the video's substance is post-hoc rationalization. In short, the accuracy of the human mind is highly variable, and two of the greatest factors in it are the will and the education of the individual. People's minds are less accurate when they are trying less hard to be accurate, but people are also perfectly capable of knowing reality. People in this highly prosperous society are often pampered and lazy, and rely excessively on social conformity as a means of establishing what is true. This does seem to be part of the video's thesis, and I agree with it strongly. But it is almost the hidden part. The major part of the video's thesis is that people are automatically pre-determined to have flawed, inaccurate cognition, by our biology and aspects of our psychology which are not subject to change, thus making the truth inherently illusive. That is the nihilistic element of the thesis that comes closer to the video's horrible title. It is established by the video by bad reasoning on every point.

I don't see how the alternative moral of the story is terribly different from what the video ends on. Both say we need to slow down sometimes, and not just jump for what intuition initially tells us. The only subtle difference is how often we should do that. I don't really see a big problem with "usually slow down and don't let intuition be the last word". Yes, it takes longer to decide things, but recovering from mistakes born of haste is often MUCH more costly (in terms of time, not to mention other limited resources) than the thinking time/effort. There is a reason that we need to be constantly reminded that "an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure", "look before you leap", "measure twice, cut once", "work smarter, not harder", "a stitch in time saves nine", etc.

I believe that one major reason we don't do more slow effortful thinking is culture. From what I can tell, deliberateness is given low value; whereas, the appearance of decisiveness is highly valued. As a result, everyone around us is telling us to quit yer egg-heading, and take action. It's not just a matter of reforming our individual thinking; we need social rewards, just like with all effortful/virtuous behaviors.

PS: Thinking Fast and Slow is the greatest book of all time.

“Images with higher contrast are perceived by the brain with more cognitive ease …” This is a causal fallacy. Images with higher contrast generally place greater emphasis on the subject, which serves to simplify the visual stimulus, and thus creates cognitive ease. However, images with high contrast could also create cognitive unease through over-stimulation, and images with low contrast could equally create cognitive ease by emphasising the subject through other methods (composition, colour, subject matter, vignette, etc.). The images used to illustrate this point are also deceptive. Humans are instinctively attracted to light and to warm colours, so the image of a warmly illuminated Golden Gate Bridge is particularly attractive for reasons in addition to its high contrast. The before-and-after Instagram filter images do not even show an increase in contrast; in fact, they show a boost in shadow luminosity, which actually results in a decrease in contrast, the opposite of what Derek claimed they show.
For a channel grounded in the scientific method, that claims to be educative, and in a video that tries to deal with the issue of cognitive bias, I am disappointed that it would present fallacious arguments and deceptive evidence.

Neuron activation potential drops the more it is activated by way of dendritic and axonal terminal growth.

The more you activate a neuron, the easier it activates in the future.

Conversely, the less you activate a neuron, the more it withers until it dies.

That’s the underling mechanic behind “cognitive ease” and “emotional dysfunction.” The more often you feel anxiety, the easier it is to be anxious. The more often you get angry, the easier it is to be angry. The more often you are offended, the easier it is to be offended.

Derrick,

Nothing illustrates your point of cognitive ease better than your referring to our evolutionary roots. We have all heard this story so many times (we came down from the trees and learned to walk and use our hands to make tools, buzza buzza) that it seems easy to believe. The actual truth is far from that.

"Evolved it for a reason" is an oxymoron.
Evolution is by necessity an absolutely purposeless and unreasoned process unless you believe that it is being guided by God. If you do believe it is guided by God, you open up to the question of whether it is even the correct explanation for the origin of species (rather than only subspecies).
Cognitive ease (from a purely evolutionary perspective) exists for the same reason cancer, trisomy 21, and any other genetic disorder exists. Random chance. Which makes it questionable whether it is useful at all, along with reason itself. After all, if logic itself is the product of randomness and pragmatism; there's no real reason it should correspond well to what is actually fundamentally true. You can explain lots of things in enormous detail (even well enough to make predictions) and still be radically off the mark from the truth. EG early models of the solar system that were far more complex and could actually predict the motions of planets and stars, but turned out as we consider now not to be true. Unless the universe was created to be intelligible/we were created to be able to understand the universe, we have no reason to trust our own logic and reason as a method of discerning truth.

If you model the brain in a neural net, repetition of the stimulus increases the 'weight' of a neuron. It makes it 'easier'/more likely to walk that specific path again. If the same node had multiple associations, the same thing happens in generative networks.
So in the news-paper thing, probably, if you ask people to come up with a nonsense word, you'd get the same kind of letter combinations from the words they were exposed to more often in each group.
Also a study showed people are more likely to pick things (jobs, cities to live in etc) that start with the first letter of their own name. It seems logical, for most of us, that would be the first letter you ever learned, helping to define the concept of a letter, the concept of reading.
The Kardashians also look symmetrical in their faces, coming close to the platonic model of a face, which is what generally is considered beauty.
Cognitive ease also explains why rhyming was considered true (and this principle is still used in advertising)

The irony of the otherwise interesting video is the large jumps to conclusions re. neuroscience and evolutionary theory. When describing neuropsychological phenomena all attributions of causation are highly provisional at best. Same with evolutionary stories. It’s ok to say “we probably evolved such a feature bc x” but, due to the nature of the discipline, no one can ever really know what circumstances resulted in any adaptation, unless we can observe it happening directly. Such information is not preserved in the organism.

IOW when you are guessing (or repeating some science popularizer’s guess) you should say so. Albeit that won’t result in “cognitive ease.”

I don't know if there is anything to the hypothesis or theory of cognitive ease, but there is nothing convincing here, because other factors have not been eliminated.  The most obvious, e.g., is the fact that repetition provides an accumulation of evidence to be considered.  So if some proposition (P) is heard repeatedly through life, or even given in the news over the last week, and the proposition (-P) is not given equal repetition, then all else being equal, people will of course tend to believe P because most of the relevant evidence they've been given supports it.

In the context of a research environment where the vast bulk of psych studies are non-replicable, all these 'cognitive bias' and 'cognitive fallacy' tropes should be set aside until there is solid evidence for them. (There are so many of them - they number in the dozens - and basically give a 'pick list' for amateur curve-fitters and p-hackers).

Show me a psych study that is not based on N<20 18-25 year old college students with zero payoff for thinking about the issue.

In other words, most psych studies use a small, non-random sample where the participants have literally zero incentive to actually deploy their cognitive apparatus (because there is no payoff differential for making the 'correct' decision: they get their participation fee whether they think hard, or just pull an answer out of their butt).

For the record, this is why I have such an intense antipathy for the 'work' of Kahnemann and Tversky, and Ariely - arbitrageurs from psych and management, into economics, whose stuff is risible-but-popular because it enables halfwits to pretend they possess deep insight into human activity.

What they have made a splash with, is 'refuting' the implications of an undergraduate pedagogical model of economic activity (a model that is used because of its mathematical tractability and its conformity with some stylised facts). They do this using game structures where the payoff differential is as near to zero as makes no odds (e.g., a choice between two different types of candy); when the participants' decisions are shown not to conform with an undergraduate understanding of consumer behaviour (i.e., strict, instantaneous, constrained marginal-utility-equalisation) they then claim that they have 'refuted' the notion that consumers are rational - using a different definition of the word 'rational' to its precise use in economics.

In fact, they unwittingly show that the allocation-decision for economic agents is sensitive to the payoff differential: if two outcomes of a decision fork have negligible difference in payoff, the 'correct' amount of effort dedicated to making a decision between them... is likewise near-zero .

In asking people to assess the truth of a statement, you did not choose well. You asked them if the following is necessarily true: "Roses are flowers. Some flowers fade. Therefore, some roses fade."
Let us denote by p the statement "Roses are flowers. "; by q let's denote "Some flowers fade."; and let's denote by r the statement "Some roses fade.". Then we can represent the thing that you asked them to assess (not an English sentence, because I wrote it above as three English sentences) by the propositional notation

(p & q) --->r.

No doubt, all of your interviewees have seen a faded rose, or already believes that r is true. Consequently, it is reasonable for them to answer with "yes", because any prepositional truth assignment that assigns the truth value "true" to r must assign the truth value "true" to (p & q) --->r.

Thus you made an error in pedagogy. Your question to them does not remove enough of the world that they have observed to force them to think in terms of predicate logic, and to force them to discern between necessary truth and contingent truth. In fact, to most people, the distinction between truth and necessary truth is lost, not because of the way our brains are wired to accept as true things which are repeated to us often, as you intimated, but because most people aren't educated in that very distinction which your example is intended to illustrate. If you had asked them in a different way, then you're likely to have elicited from them a correct answer (at least more often).

Pedagogically, this could have been done through the use of a fictional world. For example, you could have told them that you're writing an episode of "The Orville", and you're having the crew meet a new race, the Blegvard, from a planet with three suns. Then you could say that some Blegvardian's skin tone fades. Then you could ask them if it necessarily follows that rose colored Blegvardian's skin tone fades. This would be like asking them if every person watching your episode would have to conclude from seeing that there's a green Blegvardian whose skin tone fades that the skin tone of all Blegvardians fades. This is the first order error that you seemed (to me) to think you were eliciting in asking about roses, namely an error in quantifier usage. If we denote by r' the statement "The skin of some rose toned Blegvardians fades.", then r' is analogous to the statement r in my illustration above of your example with roses. Let's denote by p' the statement "All rose toned Blegvardians are Blegvardians.", and by q', let's mean the statement "Some Blegvardian's skin fades.". Then the truth of the statement

(p' & q') --->r'

cannot be determined based solely on the information that we see in your episode that done green toned Blegvardian's skin faded. This then highlights the need for a predicate formulation (in first order logic or higher order logic) of the sentences in question. Let B(x) denote the claim "x is a Blegvardian", let F(x) denote "the skin tone of x faded", let R(x) denote "x is a rose toned Blegvardian". Then p' is the sentence (\forall x)[R(x)--->B (x)], q' is the sentence (\exists y)[B(y)--->F (y)], and r' is the sentence (\exists z)[R(z)&F (z)]. Thus you could have asked them if the following sentence is necessarily true:

[(\forall x)[R(x)--->B (x)]&(\exists y)[B(y)--->F (y)]]--->(\exists z)[R(z)&F (z)].

To most people on the street, this may appear complicated, but I assure you that with the proper education in simple first order logic, it is not complicated at all. But the use of different variables in my first order formulation is not necessary. I could have used the variable x in all three of p', q', and r'. However, doing so would more likely lead some people with less practice to get the wrong answer due to a technicality, and NOT due to a lack of understanding of the distinction between quantifiers or the inability to recognize (at least intuitively) an incorrect usage of syllogism. This is why I formulated the first order version of the problem using three distinct variables: I want to give an example of the same propositional form as yours that will illustrate the distinction between necessary truth and contingent truth, without biasing the audience with an appeal to their knowledge or belief about the (necessarily contingent) truth of the claim r'.

Then, anyone who answers that the statement

[(\forall x)[R(x)--->B (x)]&(\exists y)[B(y)--->F (y)]]--->(\exists z)[R(z)&F (z)]

Is necessarily true, or equivalently, that the argument "We saw a Blegvardian's skin fade, so some rose toned Blegvardian's skin fades." is a valid argument, necessarily either is undereducated in logic for the problem at hand, or may have a cognitive disability of some sort.

The correct answer to the roses problem is that it is literally both true and false at the same time, those answers exist in a state of superposition due to both true and false having the exact same probability of being true.       To explain:     The last statement saying something to the effect: "... therefore some roses fade quickly." contains a logical fallacy that points us towards the correct answer. -- Logically it's impossible for 'some roses' to fade quickly within the context of the previous two statements: "All roses are flowers, some flowers fade quickly" because we aren't subdividing the set of flowers that fade quickly therefore either the set containing all roses will fade quickly or the entire set won't - the set of roses won't be included in the set of 'some flowers fade quickly', to break this would be to either mean this subset of roses who fade can no longer be called roses or the initial set of roses doesn't contain everything called a rose - which is paradoxical. So then you must either replace the word 'roses' with 'flowers' in last statement 'therefore some roses fade quickly' - which is logically valid given that 'some flowers' contain the set of all roses where the set of 'some roses' cannot (I'm short-cutting having to deal with the infinities related to the endless subdividing the set of roses into endless subdivisions of subdivisions etc you would get if you allow a subset of roses to fade quickly - either the entire set of roses can or it can't - regardless you still end up at the same conclusion) - or you must conclude that the statements are logically absurd to which it would literally be meaningless to attach a true or false value to.              Include with this the fact that we don't know given the information within the three statements whether or not the set in the third statement 'some roses' includes the set of roses we can only give an answer regarding whether the statement is true or false as some probability regarding whether or not true or false is more likely and given that they are both exactly equally likely to occur we must conclude that the answer is both true and false at exactly the same time -- until such a time we can determine with certainty if the set 'some flowers' contains the set of roses.         So the actual answer to the question is either a; the question is invalid or b; both true and false are both correct but not either individually.

The roses statement is true.  Just because roses aren't "necessarily" part of "some" flowers doesn't mean they necessarily aren't.  "Some" flowers is not defined as a particular variety, so the fact that "some" roses do, in fact, fade quickly puts them in the general category of some flowers that fade quickly.  Had the statement been "some varieties of flowers fade quickly", then the statement would be false since there is no metric by which to say that roses "quickly" fade as a general rule for the variety.

Hidden Dangers

Science uses the scientific method to ensure evidence is presented within theories etc correctly.

Theories are (then) considered "provisional truths" while the scientific community engages in rigorous debate - called the process of disproof - to root out anomalies and errors.

The reason why science operates in this manner is because:

Delusion is defined as, an idiosyncratic belief or impression maintained despite being contradicted by reality or rational argument.

For this reason: science seeks to avoid formulating theories that contain error - using stringent methodologies that castigate idiosyncratic beliefs.

However ... science, by its own admission, is progressing within the remit of perpetual error - under the assumption the process of disproofing is fool proof.

This is because: every theory, being subject to correction, is (potentially) an idiosyncratic belief - and given the fact science does not deal in proofs: there is no way to confirm or falsify any theory (regardless of rational argument).

This is to say: science cannot (ever) broach the subject of what causes delusion - because the interpretation of data, being arbitrary, is subject to the error of those who are biased.

Take, for example, the Laws of Gravity which stipulates the effects of gravity is instantaneous.

This was originally laughed at by the French - but Newton persevered and convinced the community to believe it is.

This was until Einstein demonstrated the curvature of space time means the effects of gravity is not instataneous.

This means the whole scientific community maintained an idiosyncratic belief until Einstein submitted his Theory of Relativity (which remains contested) to this day.

Science discovered the speed of light is not a constant (unless it is within a vacuum) - which means the Theory of Relativity, which is based on the speed of light being a constant, has a flaw.

The delusional then argue light is a constant and ignore the fact there is no vaccum in nature - to maintain the belief (theory).

The point is ... science cannot prove anything because it does not deal in proofs - which means every theory is potentially an idiosyncratic belief.

This is to say: science is a religious institution that refuses to acknowledge its doctrines causes delusions.

Everyone is free to believe what they want to believe - and, as such, I appreciate people are going to cling to whatever mechanism allows them to justify their own prejudices toward truth.

Facts do not care how you feel.
Truth does care how you feel.

The truth will set you free - from all the delusions created by men.

My Best Wishes 💖 To Everyone

No impression --- leads to familiarity --- leads to a general positive. However, repetition of NEGATIVE EXPERIENCE or experiencing a new word in a negative context will cause a negative impression / understanding of that word.

In short, all repetition isn't created equal!

Repeated exposure to an unknown word with:

:: little or no context = comes to feel good and true
(I'd like to see how this actually plays out with self-proclaimed skeptics, victims of violence, victims of fraud and other individuals with strong negative life experiences.)

:: negative context = will leave a negative feeling/understanding of the word and can even lead to incorrect negative assignment to higher classifications! (negative experiences with an instance of a class can lead to drastic conclusions of the entire class... aka a form of racism)

None of this matches my experience, outside of the "song thing" only because I'm forced to watch garbage like __ Needs Talent. Repetition makes associations easier, but those associations aren't the same as a feeling of truth. Cottage -> cheese is an easy association, but it's not going to make me believe the assertion that all cottages are made of cheese is true. There's a sanity-check step that such a logical leap would be skipping. You ask which of the two is more true, supplying two birth dates for Albert Einstein, one of which I couldn't read. My answer was "I don't know" because I literally don't know when he was born and I'd be making a blind guess whichever one I pick. The same for a chicken's body temperature.

I've seen assertions like these on Brain Games and the like, and they're all predicated on people simply not choosing the "I don't know" option. Maybe that's a common thing - not wanting to admit you don't know when you very clearly don't know and are at best guessing - but that's just not something that I've met through experience. I teach classes at the university and "I don't know" is the most common answer I get to questions regardless of the consequences of asking them.

The flowers example is not false, it just doesn't follow. The problem is that you are reading the statement as "Therefore some roses fade quickly" rather than: "Therefore: "Some roses fade quickly.""

It is quite usual to include the "therefore" in the conclusion. It is technically correct to say that that "It is not the case that "therefore some roses fade quickly"" or "it is not the case that it follows that "some roses fade quickly"". The negation of that is "It is the case that it follows that "some roses fade quickly"", which is false. But, importantly, you can't derive this logically at all with the given premises (you need all the ancillary premises of logic itself).

"Some roses fade quickly" is neither true nor false in terms of the argument. You only call it false because you are changing the rules of the game halfway through, which is very, very naughty (tut tut).

What this example demonstrates is that people will resort to a sense of reasonableness (soundness) when faced with a poorly phrased question.

I have an opposing thought: cognitive ease is learned, not automatic. I was diagnosed with aspergers years ago, and after years of deep diving into my own head, I understand it's workings decently well. My familiarity with a topic seems to do little to influence my perception of truth, likely because (1) my default truth value is null rather than true/false and is therefore inactionable, and (2) I have little emotional attachment to familiarity. These traits resulted in my skipping usual childhood steps of automatically adopting the behavior of others around me, including cognitive ease.

0:45 into the video: 14x37=? I did this in my head, for practice. I broke it down into bite-sized chunks. 14x37 is the same as 10x37 + 4x37. It's easy to remember that 10x37 is 370. Keep that number in memory. The harder part is 4x37. Well, that's just twice 2x37. It's easy to figure out that 2x37 is 74, and twice that is 148. So to get the final answer, we must add 370 and 148. I'll borrow 30 from 148, and add it to 370, that gives me 400 + 118. From there, it's easy to calculate the final answer as 518. Many simple algebra problems can be broken down to smaller chunks and done in the head without a calculator, even if you're not a genius. This also works with fractions, you just have to be clever about how you break it down into bite-sized chunks.

Its funny, years ago a friend told me ducks' quacks don't echo. I was about to file it away in "neat but useless" section of my brain when a red flag went up. Are there sounds that don't echo? I paused for a second recalling sound is nothing but waves in a medium that we can hear. Since waves reflect under most circumstances and an echo is more or less a reflected wave AND that ducks' quakes are almost certainly NOT the kind that wouldn't reflect, I came to the rapid conclusion that they do in fact echo.

I told my friend that I was pretty sure they did indeed echo. He said, "Oh no, I've heard it from other people too." I laid out my reasoning why I thought it was wrong. "No, no, too many people have all said the same thing. Its gotta be true." So, we did what any two people in an argument would do, we turned to Google.

Turns out that a LOT of people agreed with my friend. Ducks quacks don't echo. The problem is that they do. People have run experiments to prove it. And yet, people will forever think they don't echo. Damn you, cognitive ease. You make skeptics' lives much harder than they need to be.

I think cognitive ease can be broken into two separate ideas. Namely, 1) that we like simple, "easy to understand" answers, and 2) that we like answers that make us feel good on an emotional level.

I think it's best to treat these two elements separately. The first element is a relatively constant bias that we can adjust for without too much difficulty. The second element varies wildly based on a person's particular emotional state. This makes it much harder to recognize and address.

For example, even though they might both prefer simple answers, someone who's angry might prefer the "truth" that validates his/her anger and gives them an outlet, whereas someone who's scared might prefer the "truth" that makes them feel the safest.

The problem of 'cognitive ease' speaks directly to the education community (and those pulling their strings) and their responsibility to remove verifiably false and unverifiable information from the classroom, and teach only what we currently actually know to be true because of actual supportive evidence, with the understanding that what we 'know' can (and will) change, but only when properly validated evidence is available, and said evidence justifies such a change, while always seeking 'new truths' (i.e. science).

Moreover, the education community should also 'undo' the damage done from 'cognitive ease' by teaching people critical thinking skills and how to find evidence (and how to properly check things presented as evidence to make sure it's valid) to find out if things are true or not.

The balance of 'everyday life' (so that it doesn't take an hour to choose a new toothbrush, or what to eat for dinner) is a learnable skill, and critical thinking need not be so difficult as to cause psychosis.

We adapted cognitive ease over time during points of our evolution where it was useful.
In this modern age where a person is much more likely to be lied to than eaten by a wild animal, it is much less useful.
Because we can control our own evolution now, if we want to survive, we should...but in a responsible way that will ensure our survival to the best of our abilities.

Before, it was in our best intrest (because of odds) to think there 'might' be something dangerous in the bushes and decide to run away (best chance of survival), as opposed to sticking around with the posibility of being wrong (less than 'best chance' of survival), but modern humans (should) have the cognitive skills to discern fact from fiction, and be able to use those skills to determine the proper action.

"Either a thing is true or it isn't. If it is true, you should believe it, and if it isn't, you shouldn't. {and} If you can't find out whether it's true or whether it isn't, you should suspend judgment." -- Bertrand Russell

Just a quick comment. When you asked if the argument "All roses are flowers. Some flowers fade quickly. Therefore, some roses fade quickly" is true, note that the conclusion is not necessarily false. It's possible that roses are in the set of flowers that do in fact fade quickly; however, the problem with the argument is that the premise "some flowers fade quickly" is not true in all possible circumstances, so the conclusion does not logically follow from your premises. It could be true or false, but the conclusion doesn't logically follow in all possible circumstances.

I don't think this information is right. Every experiment you produced seems heavily flawed. The live interview for that roses question was answered that way because it was a question that seemed to have no right answer and the fact that roses wilt was the thing that registered while the some part was pretty hard to equate to true or false. It might be possible that roses usually don't fade quickly or possible that roses usually do fade quickly depending on the person's understanding of roses or even the source of roses they collect from. Additionally, the style of the question and questioning brings to mind a lecture, where the right answer is expected to be given to the student after they fail. Lastly, the idea that some flowers fade quickly could be seen as a ratio thing. If "some" - a ratio of flowers - wilts quickly, that ratio would still apply to the roses. Most people do not think about how different species of flowers would wilt at different rates. When a weird question like that is asked, you try to answer with your familiarity and understanding as best as possible, especially when the question is not repeated nor a type of question the person has likely been adjusted to answering within their life time. (There are many, many times when spoken questions are answered poorly until someone else in an audience gets a question correct and the people can start thinking alongside the psychology of the person asking the question.) When it is presented in test format on a piece of paper, people have different expectations. With the hard-to-read font used, most people would associate it with novelty information - books that are not fact-checked and scientific. Therefore, they would expect the proposed information to be false. With the more serious easy-to-read font, people are more prone to think the answer is true based on how it resembles tests devised by teachers. Since their teacher asked the question and they did not know about the subject, they are going to assume that the answer is true because that is usually safer on tests.

All the facts I've ever seen run counter to it, and the only "proof" I've seen presented that hasn't been proven false (by facts) are mathematical models, which aren't facts, they're educated guesses (and have already been repeatedly disproven by time or proof of invalid data and replaced with new models).  As a mathematician, I can tell you that models are nothing but a best guess scenario, and the more variables are involved, the less likely your result is to be accurate.  Needless to say, global climate is impacted by a massive number of variables, making accurate mathematical prediction near impossible (except through sheer luck).  However, due to "the illusion of truth" many fall for this and all the legislation they try to push in its name.  This is made even easier by the fact that the climate is ALWAYS changing, whether we do anything or not, as it has since the Earth was formed, making it the perfect tool, since any individual anomaly can then be blamed on Climate Change, regardless of the actual reason.  Worse than that, it distracts away from the REAL environmental issue we CAN have an impact on, pollution.  I'm an environmentalist, seeking changes based on facts, not politically pushed falsehoods.  Look at how often Climate Change, which is unproven, is thrown around, while the real, proven threat of pollution (not carbon dioxide, but actual toxic pollution of air, oceans & groundwater), which CAN be directly linked to poor manufacturing practices & other human activities.  However, problems that CAN be solved aren't nearly as useful to idealists & politicians as a nebulous idea that can be blamed for anything & never like be actually resolved to any degree of satisfaction, even if it were to finally be proven. Whilst I agree that perceived truth is an illusion, I would argue that the reason why is because when we are born, we are completely deprived of the knowledge of who we are in relation to what we experience on this supposed physical plane and where we come from.  For all we know, we could actually be somewhere other than where we think we are in some kind of virtual reality, which if accurate, could invalidate everything we believe to be true, and without knowing who we are and where we come from, that is a perfectly plausible explanation.  The only thing we know for certain is that we are having this experience in this moment; anything else is completely open to individual interpretation, because it is impossible to prove anything beyond that as a result of the restrictions the five sense human experience places on us.
